articles.author: SARAH EL DEEB, BASSEM MROUE and TIA GOLDENBERG
articles.description: DAMASCUS, Syria (AP) — Syria's prime minister said Monday that most Cabinet ministers are still working from offices in Damascus after rebels entered the capital over the weekend and overthrew President Bashar Assad.
articles.title: Syrian premier says government still functioning but foreign and domestic challenges loom

articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.description: Israeli strikes killed at least six people in the central Gaza Strip, Palestinian medical officials said Monday, while also hitting suspected chemical and long-range weapons sites in Syria to keep them from rebels who seized Damascus.
articles.title: Middle East latest: Israeli strikes hit Gaza and also target suspected weapons sites in Syria

articles.author: KAREEM CHEHAYEB and ABDULRAHMAN SHAHEEN
articles.description: DAMASCUS, Syria (AP) — Bashar Barhoum woke in his dungeon prison cell in Damascus at dawn Sunday, thinking it would be the last day of his life.
articles.title: Syrian rebels free prisoners from Assad's notorious dungeons who celebrate in Damascus streets

articles.author: HYUNG-JIN KIM and KIM TONG-HYUNG
articles.description: SEOUL, South Korea (AP) — South Korea’s Justice Ministry on Monday imposed an overseas travel ban on President Yoon Suk Yeol as authorities investigate allegations of rebellion and other charges in connection with his short-lived declaration of martial law last week.
articles.title: South Korea's Justice Ministry imposes a travel ban on President Yoon over martial law

articles.author: CHRIS MEGERIAN
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — In the history of American politics, there's no shortage of presidents who promised to shake up Washington once they got to the White House. But Donald Trump may prove to be in a class of his own, and he appears more interested in beating the federal government into submission than recalibrating it.
articles.title: In promising to shake up Washington, Trump is in a class of his own

articles.author: TAMMY WEBBER
articles.description: Earth just experienced its second-warmest November on record — second only to 2023 — making it all but certain that 2024 will end as the hottest year ever measured, according to a report Monday by European climate service Copernicus.
articles.title: Second-warmest November on record means that 2024 is likely to be Earth's hottest year, report says

articles.author: MICHAEL R. SISAK and CEDAR ATTANASIO
articles.description: NEW YORK (AP) — The search for UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson ’s killer since Thompson was ambushed Wednesday outside a Midtown Manhattan hotel has stretched beyond New York City.
articles.title: A timeline of the fatal shooting of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson and search for his killer

articles.author: TIA GOLDENBERG
articles.description: JERUSALEM (AP) — Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is set to take to the witness stand Tuesday for the first time in his trial on corruption allegations, a pivotal point in the drawn-out proceedings that comes as the leader wages war in Gaza and faces an international arrest warrant for war crimes charges.
articles.title: Netanyahu is set to take the witness stand for the first time in his corruption trial in Israel

articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.description: The silent black-and-white surveillance camera video of the Russian missile attack in the Ukrainian city of Dnipro was brief but chilling: Six huge fireballs pierced the darkness and slammed into the ground at astonishing speed.
articles.title: Russia has used its hypersonic Oreshnik missile for the first time. What are its capabilities?

articles.author: ANNA FURMAN
articles.description: The results of the 2024 U.S. presidential election rattled the country and sent shockwaves across the world — or were cause for celebration, depending on who you ask.
articles.title: ‘Polarization’ is Merriam-Webster’s 2024 word of the year
